title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
text:
#importing libraries:
library(lattice)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
section: Loading the data and building the first matrix:
text:
Loading the data and building the first matrix:

#three categories of employment:

total_empl= c (612, 157, 77 ,45, 18)
salaried= c( 505, 62, 59, 33, 14)
hourly= c(107, 95, 18, 12,4)

empl_mat = cbind(total_empl, salaried, hourly)
empl_mat

     total_empl salaried hourly
[1,]        612      505    107
[2,]        157       62     95
[3,]         77       59     18
[4,]         45       33     12
[5,]         18       14      4

rownames(empl_mat) = c( "White", 
                              "Black", "Asian", "Hispanic or Latino", 
                              "Two or More Races")

empl_mat

                   total_empl salaried hourly
White                     612      505    107
Black                     157       62     95
Asian                      77       59     18
Hispanic or Latino         45       33     12
Two or More Races          18       14      4

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
text:
Building the data frame:

empl_df <- as.data.frame(empl_mat) %>%
  rownames_to_column(var = "Category") %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = total_empl:hourly, 
               names_to = "Employment_Type", 
               values_to = "Count")

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
section: Plotting the number of employees based on their race:
text:
Plotting the number of employees based on their race:

ggplot(empl_df, aes(x = Category, y = Count, group = Employment_Type, color = Employment_Type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Employment by Type Across Different Races",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Number of Employees",
       color = "Employment Type") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
text:
Add Gender Data
To examine the difference of employment rate using gender, we must update the data frame to include the number of female and male employees.

emply2_df <- data.frame(
  Race = c("White", "Black", "Asian", "Hispanic or Latino", "Two or More Races"),
  Female = c(612, 157, 77, 45, 18),
  Male = c(950 - 612, 950 - 157, 950 - 77, 950 - 45, 950 - 18)
)

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
text:
Reshaping the data:

emply2_df_long <- emply2_df %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = Female:Male, names_to = "Gender", values_to = "Count")


# Calculating percentages within each race


emply2_df_long <- emply2_df_long %>%
  group_by(Race) %>%
  mutate(Percentage = Count / sum(Count) * 100)

title: R Code: The Washington Post Employment Examination
section: Creating a stacked bar graph with percentages of female and male employees
text:
Creating a stacked bar graph with percentages of female and male employees

ggplot(emply2_df_long, aes(x = Race, y = Count, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(round(Percentage, 1), "%")),
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5)) +  # Positioning labels inside bars
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Number of Employees by Race and Gender",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Number of Employees",
       fill = "Gender") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Washington Post: Employment Rate Based on Race and Gender
text:
In 2019, The Washington Post performed a study on the pay gap of employees at the post and addressed that their study shows that a pay gap does indeed exist across different genders and races. You can read more about the article here .
Some visualizations made by the Washington Post included making a bar graph that represents the number of the employees based on their race. the study explored races, White, Black, Asian, Hispanic or Latino, Two or more races as shown in figure 1 below.



Figure 1: Employment Visualization Based on Race


Nonetheless, this visualization could be improved by showcasing the correlation between the gender an race and how they affect the pay of the respective employees.



To improve this visualization, we first examined the employment of employees based on their race using a line graph. This comparison showed us that there is indeed a difference in employment rates based on the race of the employees. We can see that the highest increase in number of employees was the number of white employees., thereby suggesting a preference in hiring salaried white employees when compared to other races such as Hispanic or Latino employees. On the other hand, the different categories of employment presented highlighted black employees have the highest hourly employment rate when compared to employees with other races as shown in Figure 2.





Figure 2: Visualization of Employment Type Across Different Races







Next, we compared the number of employees hired by the Washington Post based on their race and gender. First, we calculated the percentages of male and female employees in each race. Then, we utilized a stacked bar graph to represent the difference in employment rates based on both factors, gender and race. We can see that gender has a big impact on employment rates as shown in Figure 3. Furthermore, male employees are show to be in favor when compared to the females hired as the study showed that 98.1% of males with two or more races were shown to be male employees, followed by the Asian, Hispanic or Latino, and Black categories closely. On the other hand, it was clear to see that there is a higher percentage of White female women employees when compared to the White male employees hired by the post. Therefore, there is a huge difference in employment rates based on the gender and race.





Figure 3: Visualization of Employment Rate Based on Gender







In this project, we explored how to enhance visualizations by choosing which variables to work with. For instance, we created a line graph instead of the bar graph provided by the original study to examine the difference in employment rates by the Washington Post. The line graph in this case is a better choice of visualization as it showcases the different categories of employment (hourly and salaried) and clarifies the comparison between the total number of employees across different races. Moreover, a stacked bar was a good visualization choice to examine the difference in employment rates as it showcases the different numbers of employees within each race of employees in the Post Office.

title: About

Cory Trainor

title: New York Times: High School Sports Injuries
text:
In 2019 the New York Times published an article titled “Inside Football’s Campaign to Save the Game.” The article examined the sport’s culture and focused on the growing number of injuries among young players and the long term effects of these injuries. You can read the full article here.
Pictured below is one of the figures used to compare the number of injuries sustained by high school boys in six popular sports: football, hockey, wrestling, lacrosse, soccer, and basketball. (Belson, Bui, Drape, Taylor, & Ward, 2019)







Figure 1


The figure offers an interesting comparison of the relative number of injuries, but without reading the numbers it is difficult to quickly compare the sports.



First, we compared the total number of injuries sustained during competition in each sport. The numbers of injuries are reported as injuries per 10,000 competition plays.





Figure 2




As you can see in the above graphic, the total number of recorded football injuries was over twice the number of any other sport in the surveyed population. This is not immediately apparent in the original figure. Grouping the injuries in a stacked bar chart better presents the sharp contrast between the total injuries sustained by football athletes compared to other high school sports.



Next, let’s take a look at the number of injuries sustained by type, or by what body part was injured.





Figure 3




Football leads nearly all of the injury categories in the surveyed population. The figure below allows you to more easily compare the injury categories by sport.





Figure 4







The statistic that is most troubling to researchers and parents alike is the significant number of head injuries sustained by high school boys playing football. Head injuries are particularly dangerous for developing brains and, increasingly, head injuries have been linked to mental illness in teenage boys. (Bracken, Branch, Laffin, Lieberman, & Ward, 2023)
The total number of head injuries sustained by football players was nearly double that of hockey players, the sport that sustained the next most head injuries.





Figure 5










Belson, K., Bui, Q., Drape, J., Taylor, R., & Ward, J. (2019, November 7). On Defense: Inside Football’s Campaign to Save the Game. New York Times.
Bracken, K., Branch, J., Laffin, B., Lieberman, R., & Ward, J. (2023, November 16). C.T.E. Study Finds That Young Football Players Are Getting the Disease. New York Times.

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#Entries represent injuries sustained per 10,000 competitions in the named sport
football <- c(34,21,3,5,11,7,18,3,19)
hockey <- c(18,13,2,2,5,8,3,1,5)
wrestling <- c(14,7,4,2,2,1,7,1,3)
lacrosse <- c(11,3,1,2,4,3,9,1,4)
soccer <- c(11,1,1,2,2,5,5,2,6)
basketball <- c(7,1,1,2,4,2,3,1,13)

mat <- cbind (football, hockey, wrestling, lacrosse, soccer, basketball)
injury <- c("Head","Shoulder","Arm","Trunk","Hand","Thigh","Knee","Lower Leg","Ankle")
sport <- c("Football","Hockey","Wrestling","Lacrosse","Soccer","Basketball")
colnames(mat) <- sport
rownames(mat) <- injury
mat

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13






#Creating data frame and adding body location as a variable
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

inj.sport <- as.data.frame(mat)
body <-rownames(inj.sport)
inj.sport$Injuries = factor(body, ordered = T, levels = rev(body))
inj.sport

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball  Injuries
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7      Head
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1  Shoulder
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1       Arm
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2     Trunk
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4      Hand
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2     Thigh
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3      Knee
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1 Lower Leg
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13     Ankle

rownames(inj.sport) = NULL
inj.sport

  Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball  Injuries
1       34     18        14       11     11          7      Head
2       21     13         7        3      1          1  Shoulder
3        3      2         4        1      1          1       Arm
4        5      2         2        2      2          2     Trunk
5       11      5         2        4      2          4      Hand
6        7      8         1        3      5          2     Thigh
7       18      3         7        9      5          3      Knee
8        3      1         1        1      2          1 Lower Leg
9       19      5         3        4      6         13     Ankle






#long pivot / gather data
inj.sport.long <- gather(inj.sport,key = Sport, value = Number, Football:Basketball, factor_key = T)
inj.sport.long

    Injuries      Sport Number
1       Head   Football     34
2   Shoulder   Football     21
3        Arm   Football      3

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Stacked Bar

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x=Sport, y = Number, fill = Injuries))+geom_col()+
  labs(y="Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays", title = "High School Sports Injuries", fill = "Injury Type")+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Line Plot

##Line Plot
ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(y = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",x="Type of Injury",title = "High School Sports Injuries", fill= "Sport")+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Facet Wrap

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(x = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",y="",title = "High School Sports Injuries")+
  facet_wrap(~Sport)+ scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,50,by =10)) +   theme_minimal()+
  theme(legend.position ="none")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Facet Grid

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(x = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",y="",title = "High School Sports Injuries")+
  facet_grid(~Sport)+ scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,50,by =10)) +   theme_minimal()+
  theme(legend.position ="none")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Head Injuries

ggplot(subset_head,aes(x=Sport, y=Number))+
  geom_col(aes(fill = Sport))+
  geom_text(aes(label = Number),vjust = -0.5)+
  labs(title = "Head Injuries by Sport",y = "Number of Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays", x="")+
  theme_minimal()
